Alan Ryan

Without wanting to create a highly technical discussion (in which I could not take part) perhaps I could start the ball rolling in this Economics forum by saying and asking :
 
 The press tend to alarm the unsophisticated public with stories about service jobs being exported to India, and jobs in the manufacturing sector being transferred to China. The implication being that unemployment will rise as a result of these efforts (by employers) to lower costs.
 
 But is there any cause for concern at this alleged net loss of American (and British) jobs to "third world" and developing countries - on the crude theory that labour costs and employer liabilities are much lower in say, India and China, and the transfer of jobs to such places is therefore essential to maintain growth and profitability ? Are the trade unions naive to worry about this trend ? What is the true economic balance likely to be in this "scare story", if it is one ?

The circle is complete when the US economy gets bad enough to affect the sales volume of the outsourcing company to the point that they are making less profit. We have companies that move their factories to cheap-labor countries and still expect to sell their goods back to the US consumer...the one who lost his job in the US.
 
 When you think about the world economy, US (British) outsourcing is great. It helps the economy of the poor country. When you think about the economy of the US (Britain), US (British) outsourcing sucks.
 
 When you think about the labor unions and their ridiculous actions, you can understand why outsourcing is all but required. The Unions did wonders for the mistreated child/slave laborers of the early industrial revolution. Benefits came in the form of increased wages and working conditions. However, the present day union practices have forced the use of cheaper labor pools in the grateful third world countries. So the slave labor has merely been obtained from another source for a while. Someday they will all form labor unions and the prices will continue to rise.
 
 We are presently supporting slave labor when we buy trinkets and clothing "Assembled in Mexico, India, Pakistan, Shrilanka, China, etc..."
 
 This goes against our principles (and our own economic health), but it's the going thing now...profit for the big boys is all that counts!

Sure is. But the capital is leaving the national economy to be invested somewhere else... Hence, capital flight.
 
 
 I understand "capital flight" to be the movement of money from one investment to another in search of greater stability or perhaps increased returns, etc. How can the outsourcing of jobs come under this umbrella ?
 
 Capital is saved in country A when people are fired in order to export their jobs to country B. How does this diminish the capital available in A ? 
 
 I ask because I don't understand.
Eddie

I understand "capital flight" to be the movement of money from one investment to another in search of greater stability or perhaps increased returns, etc. How can the outsourcing of jobs come under this umbrella ?
 
 Capital is saved in country A when people are fired in order to export their jobs to country B. How does this diminish the capital available in A ? 
 
 I ask because I don't understand.

 
 this is the thing. People are fired because production is moved to countries where there is greater return on invested capital. When the production line is moved, the capital invested in the economy moves with it. While much invested capital is hard to move (such as plants, machines, buildings etc), that capital is "phased out". Instead of re-investing in the west to uphold the capital stock, the capital is being invested in foreign countries. It is still the same companies making the products, only different workers.
 
 When such production as ship-wrighting and textiles became inefficient in Europe due to competition from third world countries, the capital was re-tained in the national economies. It was re-invested in emerging bussineses. These structural changes where in the long run good for everyone involved. The "job flight" today is not necessarily good for the western economies due to the fact that the capital is leaving as well.
Missouri Mule

Here is something to consider. When we "export" jobs to China, India or elsewhere we receive something very beneficial in return -- namely lower prices. That in turn frees up money that would otherwise be spent on domestic goods and allows us to spend for other goods and services we would not be able to afford in the absence of these savings. As these savings and subsequent spending filter through a dynamic economy as exists in the United States, new industries and technologies arise that employs new workers in new jobs. Who would have known that Microsoft would have come out of a embryonic technology, the personal computer; something that was merely a idle curiosity in the 1960s and 1970s? As that industry grew, it also yielded new vendors and their employees. 
 
 The ones who rail about outsourcing are of the same mindset who argues this is a zero sum gain. It is not and they are wrong. But it does have its casualties and the laid off workers of the buggy whip manufacturers can surely attest.

lord tammerlain

The long term effects should be a convergence of wages in industries that produce tradeable goods or services. 
 
 An assembly line worker in a developing country is going to have his/her real wages increase as an assembly line worker in a developed country has his/her real wages decline to a point where the overall cost of producing a product is similar in both countries.
 
 As for global development improving the income levels and prosperity in the US, or any other developed country. Only if they they remain competitive in a global marketplace. That competiveness may require lower income levels for certain sectors of the economy.

OK. I understand your argument: but does that mean you would support protectionist measures to prevent the export of jobs ? As I suggested before, protectionism might do more harm than good to the protected parts of an economy : What do you think ?

 
 I agree. Protectionism against imports of goods and services is a bad way to go. Not only is it questionable wether it would be possible to slow the capital flight this way, but it is also very vulnrable for being hi-jacked by special interest groups and could threaten to set off a domino chain of protektionism (think 1930:ies). 
 
 Besides, the root of the problem is capital moving, not goods and services (which ios good for almost everyone involved). I don`t know if the Tobin tax (taxation of capital movements) is possible (not even "Tobin" himself believed in it), but perhaps it could be used if both EU, USA and China (fat chance..)would implement it.
 
 Another way could perhaps be to try to raise consumer awareness of working conditions in second- and third world countries. And hopefully this would result in shifts of preferences, killing two birds with one stone (slowing the capital movements from the West as well as improve working conditions in the third world). The price for this would perhaps be more expensive goods and services as well as lower profits for multinational companies (alternatively raise unemployment and/or lower wages in the third world). 
 
 For europes part, much of the capital flight is going to eastern europe. Hopefully wages and working conditions will converge as many of the eastern european countries are growing quite fast (but by the current rate of growth it will still take at least 50 years for the fastest growing economies I think). By expanding EU eastwards, we could both quicken this process of convergance as well as encourage labour force migration (which will both quicken the convergance as well as benefit the labour force rather than the capital owners). Another aspect of this is that we could create the basis for a unified european labour movement that could protect european countries from the "race to the bottom", at least against eachother.

 That's correct. The difficulty of that inevitable adjustment lies in political circumstances in mature, Western countries where workers would understandably be aghast at their standard of living taking a 75% or more drop. If they even had a clue of the future. Politicians attempt temporary fixes using tariffs and other patches to retain popularity by job retention in a specific industry while the same problems, wage and compliance overheads creating a lack of global competitiveness, simultaneously develop in ten other markets. US steel, textiles, furniture and a multitude of other industries are graphic examples of the long-term fruitlessness of temporary support of sectors unable to remain competitive on a global basis.

And if anything, a propaganda campaign aimed at generating an idea of it being immoral to invest overseas would result in a higher rate of profit for those entrepeneurs who invested there anyway.

 
 The idea would be to impose a cost on treating employees badly by altering consumer preferences, not investment preferences. therefor, those who still would invest in bussineses that produced export goods with lousy working conditions would have to lower their prices (by cutting their own profits or lowering wages) in order to compete with those bussineses that produced export goods with good working conditions. And hopefully run most of the bad employers out of (the export) business.
georged

The problem is capital flight. When capital leaves the country, this drains the capital stock and lowers employment without increasing productivity...

 
 Correct. IMO most people fail to understand the role of capital in creating and sustaining industrial growth. While general economic discussion seemingly concentrates itself at the worker/country (emotional) levels of improving humanitarian and national circumstances, investment capital, private and multinational, has no such loyalties. Capital by its very composition demands performance resulting in acceptable returns for being exposed to risk. Prudent capitalists seek minimal risk offering maximum return without emotional attachment. 
 
 I'm not familiar with capital flight in Western Europe, but in the US it's reaching impressive levels. Low interest rates denoting negligible expansion demand are a clear indication of inactive or relocated capital. This shift will accelerate as U.S. and European markets continue to slow and become more saturated while Asian markets rapidly expand.

 Locating production in Mexico and S. American countries without politically self-serving trade restrictions that increase US consumer prices will greatly slow the influx. I`m nopt Georged, but I`ll give you my perspective anyway
 
 
Okay then, but I don't see China's labor cost rising in the near future. 

 
 China has been experiencing a huge economic expansion due to the release of huge quantities of labour reserves previously tied up in innefficient agriculture production. This has led to surplus labour that even though the chinese economy has been booming, has kept tabs on the labour costs. One could say China has been catching up (some) of what they lost by allocating the labour force inefficiently for almost 50 years. Eventually, this surplus labour will run out and labour costs will increase as well as dampen the chinese economic expansion. The question is not wether this will happen or not, but rather when it will happen. I can`t say if it will happen in the "near future" or not (it kind of depends on what you mean by "near"), but it will certainly happen within our lifetime...
 
 
 What then? How can America continue to sustain these huge trade deficits? 

 
 It shouldn`t. Let the dollar depriciate in order to achieve trade ballance. This will result in a declined standard of living, but hopefully it will end the american consumtion fest fueled by borrowing.

 China's labor cost will increase, but not in the near future, not soon enough to for the US to gradually reduce general standards of living to become competitive without a dramatic economic impact. The only real issue is how long the rest of the world, China, Asia, EU blend needs our markets until their industrial capability expands their per-capita incomes to absorb an adequate percentage of production. They can drain our national wealth in the form of trade imbalance for some time. The more immediate problem, for us and the rest of the world, is our escalating debt, associated monetary inflation and the question of how long the rest of the world can support that debt with our no longer affordable military spending and foreign aggression. 
 
 Unless we accomplish something truly dramatic like exclusive rights to a feasible alternative fuel or other global commodity, we're eventually going to take a very bad fall. Using low per-capita income countries in S. America without trade restrictions, much the same as the EU is attempting to accomplish by blending mature and under-developed countries to lower labor costs to save the mature countries, would allow us to retain control over our capital, much as a farmer retains seed for future crops. The problem we face with that, as does Europe, is convincing the American voter to halve their standard of living to save the other half. We need a tough administration who puts the country's future welfare in front of votes and with our political system that's just not going to happen. So, IMO, we'll watch the housing bubble break, consumer confidence plummet to a point below being able to show growth in our well-cooked internal transaction oriented GDP and that'll get us closer to a two-tiered society, the haves and the have nots.

They can drain our national wealth in the form of trade imbalance for some time. The more immediate problem, for us and the rest of the world, is our escalating debt, associated monetary inflation and the question of how long the rest of the world can support that debt with our no longer affordable military spending and foreign aggression. 
 
 Unless we accomplish something truly dramatic like exclusive rights to a feasible alternative fuel or other global commodity, we're eventually going to take a very bad fall. Using low per-capita income countries in S. America without trade restrictions, much the same as the EU is attempting to accomplish by blending mature and under-developed countries to lower labor costs to save the mature countries, would allow us to retain control over our capital, much as a farmer retains seed for future crops. The problem we face with that, as does Europe, is convincing the American voter to halve their standard of living to save the other half. We need a tough administration who puts the country's future welfare in front of votes and with our political system that's just not going to happen. So, IMO, we'll watch the housing bubble break, consumer confidence plummet to a point below being able to show growth in our well-cooked internal transaction oriented GDP and that'll get us closer to a two-tiered society, the haves and the have nots.

 
 I am in general agreement with your concerns but then you talk about "monetary inflation." What inflation are you talking about? It has been almost non-existent. What am I missing and where are you getting this information? Other than that I do agree with much of what you say; especially the two-tiered society. This is where the Democrats could really make hay if they had any sense.
Symbiote

By monetary inflation, he means the expansion of the money supply.
 
 In contrast to price inflation, or an increase in the "general price level", as if such a thing had any meaning.
 
 The term "inflation" one hundred years ago referred to "monetary inflation", while what we today would usually call simply "inflation" that is, rising prices, was once recognised as the consequence of inflation.
Eddie

I have to plead ignorance. What was the deal on the Krona? That must have passed right by my eyes. I didn't know you had a problem.

 
 In some ways, the situation up untill the crash resembled certain characteristics you are experiencing at the moment. We had high governmental decifits, low savings quota, inflated currency, an aging population and a trade decifit. Unlike you, our currency was fixed, we had slow real economic growth, quick stock market growth and high inflationary pressure.
 
 I don`t think you`ll be seeing the same type of problems as we eventually experienced, but certain aspects of it might be worthwile to consider.
 
 A bit simplistic and short, the problem with the krona was that it had a fixed prise, guaranteed by the government. When the capital market was liberalised and foreign speculators where allowed to purchase and sell Swedish assets, the fixed rate was impossible to maintain. When the market expected the Swedish government to devalue the Krona, the Krona cameunder a series of speculative attacks that first where fought off by the central bank selling foreign assets to purchase swedish assets. The central bank also tried to raise the interest rate (we had a 500% interest rate for a weekend... that was pretty mind boggling) bnut ultimatly the government and central bank failed to protect the Krona and it was set to float...
 
 
On the American borrowing situation; you are probably correct. We don't save. Most of the people coming out of the Great Depression are now gone or about to leave the scene. They did save because they didn't know where their next meal was coming from. Today's Americans are spoiled rotten and live like there is no tomorrow. Our coming problem that is really going to bite is the retirement problem. Look for this to come to a head if and when GM goes belly up and they shed their unfunded liabilities onto the federal government. Then all hell will break loose. For myself, we saved enough to retire early and are trying to liquidate all debt as we go into the later years. If I were a younger person I would save every dime I could because the dung is going to hit the fan in not too many years and it won't be a pretty sight as retirement plans go the way of the buggy whip.

 
 These things tend to rectify themselves. As said earlier, it might be painful for a while, but I don`t think it`s a threat to the US economy from a more long-term perspective.
Missouri Mule

By monetary inflation, he means the expansion of the money supply.
 
 In contrast to price inflation, or an increase in the "general price level", as if such a thing had any meaning.
 
 The term "inflation" one hundred years ago referred to "monetary inflation", while what we today would usually call simply "inflation" that is, rising prices, was once recognised as the consequence of inflation.

 
 Unless I am greatly mistaken, Greenspan is in fact a monetarist and controls the money supply very carefully in order to keep a check on inflation. And I am too. I have always believed that money supply and inflation run hand in hand. Therefore, if our inflation is essentially none, where is the monetary inflation and what is it exactly? I must be missing something here.
Symbiote

I've explained to you the difference between the two types of inflation, if you then go on to discuss them as simply "inflation", it makes it difficult to understand what you are saying.
 
 Monetary inflation can be measured directly. You don't check the temperature by collecting your sweat in a bucket and extrapolating, you use a thermometer. When the thermometer reads low, but you are sweating, the answer is that something other than the room temperature is causing you to sweat.
 
 If productivity rises, causing prices to decline, and simultaneously the money supply increases, causing prices to rise, prices overall might go either way, they might even go up for some goods and down for others. Prices therefore could not be used to "calculate" monetary inflation, even if you were somehow able to meaningfully define a "general price level" to measure changes in.
 
 
Greenspan is in fact a monetarist and controls the money supply very carefully in order to keep a check on inflation. 

 
 Yes, he's a genius, he knows when to stimulate the economy, but he also knows when it's overheating, he's a "Maestro" who conducts the economy with superhuman brilliance. That's the stock standard story. A monetarist is not defined as somebody who believes in "keeping a lid on inflation", that's not what the term means.
 
 
I have always believed that money supply and inflation run hand in hand.

 
 If you mean by that that a 3% increase in the money supply will result in a 3% increase in the "general price level", you are not only wrong, but saying nothing. There is no such thing as a general price level.
 
 
Therefore, if our inflation is essentially none, where is the monetary inflation and what is it exactly? 

 
 How do you know "inflation" is essentially none? Define "inflation"? Does the CPI measure "inflation"?
 
 Hint: The price of oil rose rapidly. Imported goods are much more expensive than they were two years ago. You may have noticed house prices rapidly rising.
georged

If things are bound to collapse, you should let things "collapse". Just make sure your politicians are in a situation to sothe the negative spiral. It will be painful, but you will recover. We did it back in 1992 when the Krona tanked and we had to revise our whole monetary system (it was actually worse for us than the deppression where...), we are still recovering from the collapse, but things are looking better...

 
 The US is facing much the same scenario you experienced, without your accompanying increase in wages and with floating exchange rates. Much deadlier, but with an economy so large adjustment absorption takes much longer before the moment of truth. 10% interest rates would make a very interesting what-if model of the US federal budget.
 
 On that note, to show how concerned the US government is about the general public, the US 30-year treasury note, the long bond, is slated for reintroduction in 2006. The obvious goal is a political attempt to partially contain national debt service at fixed rates in an effort to avoid tax increases and let the public cope with inflation on its own. If you haven't noticed from our foreign policy, our politicians are real humanitarians.
Missouri Mule

I've explained to you the difference between the two types of inflation, if you then go on to discuss them as simply "inflation", it makes it difficult to understand what you are saying.
 
 Monetary inflation can be measured directly. You don't check the temperature by collecting your sweat in a bucket and extrapolating, you use a thermometer. When the thermometer reads low, but you are sweating, the answer is that something other than the room temperature is causing you to sweat.
 
 If productivity rises, causing prices to decline, and simultaneously the money supply increases, causing prices to rise, prices overall might go either way, they might even go up for some goods and down for others. Prices therefore could not be used to "calculate" monetary inflation, even if you were somehow able to meaningfully define a "general price level" to measure changes in.
 
 
 
 Yes, he's a genius, he knows when to stimulate the economy, but he also knows when it's overheating, he's a "Maestro" who conducts the economy with superhuman brilliance. That's the stock standard story. A monetarist is not defined as somebody who believes in "keeping a lid on inflation", that's not what the term means.
 
 
 
 If you mean by that that a 3% increase in the money supply will result in a 3% increase in the "general price level", you are not only wrong, but saying nothing. There is no such thing as a general price level.
 
 
 
 How do you know "inflation" is essentially none? Define "inflation"? Does the CPI measure "inflation"?
 
 Hint: The price of oil rose rapidly. Imported goods are much more expensive than they were two years ago. You may have noticed house prices rapidly rising.

 
 You and your buddy are going to attack this oil inflation issue again and I'm not going to bite. If you want to believe in the tooth fairy that's your right.
 
 The bottom line is that money supply and inflation are inherently linked. When Greenspan raises the interest rate he is dong so to restrict the supply of money, which in reality is just like any other commodity, like oil or sugar. 
 
 The truth is that not very long ago, the spector of DEFLATION was much more worrisome.
georged

Yes, he's a genius, he knows when to stimulate the economy, but he also knows when it's overheating, he's a "Maestro" who conducts the economy with superhuman brilliance. That's the stock standard story. A monetarist is not defined as somebody who believes in "keeping a lid on inflation", that's not what the term means.
 

 
 Not really a difficult job in the US when over 80% of the GDP is driven by public debt and consumer spending greatly facilitated by personal debt; internal transactions. Throw in a very expensive, fruitless war, national fear of being 'attacked' and a thinly veiled siege mentality is in place to maintain government numbers that placate the public. At that point, the only criterion is maintaining consumer confidence. A very shaky house of cards.
Symbiote

The bottom line is that money supply and inflation are inherently linked. When Greenspan raises the interest rate he is dong so to restrict the supply of money, which in reality is just like any other commodity, like oil or sugar.

 
 Thanks for the tip sherlock, since I just defined monetary inflation for you as an increase in the money supply, their link should be pretty clear by now.
 
 
You and your buddy are going to attack this oil inflation issue again and I'm not going to bite.

 
 Does the word "oil" instantly cause your brain to shut down?
 
 You just did bite, you picked out oil, when my post was not about oil, and yet in doing so pointed out the absurdity of your own position.
 
 You define "inflation" as "rising prices" (I think that's sufficiently vague to accomodate your position), and yet when the price of oil rises, you claim this is "not inflation"?
georged

In contrast to price inflation, or an increase in the "general price level", as if such a thing had any meaning.
 

 
 In the US it means less than nothing as food and energy are excluded from official 'inflation' reports. A very gullible public also believes, as they've been told by government, self-serving brokerages and their media, that US interest rates are being increased to keep 'inflation' under control, failing to understand expansion of our money supply has created increased demands for higher treasury issue yields used to service our debt to offset declining exchange rates.
Missouri Mule

Thanks for the tip sherlock, since I just defined monetary inflation for you as an increase in the money supply, their link should be pretty clear by now.
 
 Does the word "oil" instantly cause your brain to shut down?
 
 You just did bite, you picked out oil, when my post was not about oil, and yet in doing so pointed out the absurdity of your own position.
 
 You define "inflation" as "rising prices" (I think that's sufficiently vague to accomodate your position), and yet when the price of oil rises, you claim this is "not inflation"?

 
 But I know where you are coming from. We had a long discussion about oil and inflation. You were wrong then. You are wrong now. 
 
 Actually, In rereading you post and your last sentence you may have inadvertently stumbled into what is driving your point of view. You say the rising price of oil is inflation. That's not true. The rising price of oil is a symptom of the scarcity of the product. And as can now be seen the price of gasoline has now decreased (because the supply has increased) even while the overall price index has started to inch upwards. Therefore the price of oil is only incidentally a product of inflation. It is a product of supply and demand, as I said earlier.
 
 As as I said also, the amount of money in circulation determines the rate of inflation. Reduce the amount of money and presto - chango, the inflation subsides or even goes into deflation. As we know all too well (at least some of us), when the supply of money was cut back during the Great Depression it exacerbated the depression. What we needed was more money; not less. But also, as some bannana republics have learned, merely printing money only leads to hyperinflation. So it works both ways, although I doubt you are capable of understanding these simple facts. 
 
 Like the laws of physics, the laws of economics do not change.
Missouri Mule

Not really a difficult job in the US when over 80% of the GDP is driven by public debt and consumer spending greatly facilitated by personal debt; internal transactions. Throw in a very expensive, fruitless war, national fear of being 'attacked' and a thinly veiled siege mentality is in place to maintain government numbers that placate the public. At that point, the only criterion is maintaining consumer confidence. A very shaky house of cards.

 
 What in the hell are you talking about? Are you off your meds today?
Symbiote

The rising price of oil is a symptom of the scarcity of the product.

 
 The price of any product is a "symptom" of the scarcity of the product for sale relative to the supply of money wanting to purchase it.
 
 
And as can now be seen the price of gasoline has now decreased (because the supply has increased) even while the overall price index has started to inch upwards.

 
 So? Many of the products within the "overall price index" have decreased while the "overall price index" rose. Does that mean that parts of the general price index do not change according to inflation? Where does that leave the "general price index" as a measure of inflation? How can it be that the prices of some goods and services (the general price index) are determined by the quantity of money in circulation (demand), while the price of others (oil) are determined by supply?
 
 
As as I said also, the amount of money in circulation determines the rate of inflation.

 
 You have yet to say what you mean by the "rate of inflation". If you mean by it, changes in the CPI, say so.
 
 The change (note: not quantity, change) in the money supply is only one factor in the determination of prices. You repeat "supply and demand", and then pick one factor or the other when it suits you.
 
 Nevertheless, this is entirely beside the point. You have simply used the issue of oil to avoid discussing the topic.
 
 I would also like to note at this juncture, that our previous discussion you refer to, ended with you being unable to answer a simple question, namely:
 
how do you account for the discrepancy in the change in cost of oil in US dollars vs the cost of oil in Australian, New Zealand or Canadian dollars, or in Euros?
Duo_Maxwell

What in the hell are you talking about? Are you off your meds today?

 
 He's not. What Georged said should be able to be easily understood by anyone who has fianance and economics background. 
 
 Not really a difficult job in the US when over 80% of the GDP is driven by public debt and consumer spending greatly facilitated by personal debt; internal transactions.
 
 Most of the GDP is funded by personal debt. The average debt in the US is over $46,000. Our MPC is ridiculous highly, meaning that for every dollar we earn, we save a paltry amount of it. As such, personal debt will obvious expand when the crunch comes every so often. Normally in a rational society, people don't spend like that, and we saw that post 9/11 with a wait and see attitude. GDP is dependent upon consumer confidence. If consumer confidence drops, then the GDP drops as seen post 9/11 and during Bush Sr's 1991-1992 campagin. Consumer confidence really has no stable foundation. Such is the problem with relying upon it for GDP growth.
georged

Consumer confidence really has no stable foundation. Such is the problem with relying upon it for GDP growth.

 
 The present administration has a lot of balls in the air. Positive consumer confidence is a key component of their economic policy. When a GDP with the composition we've criminally structured is threatened, using fear to expand public and personal spending has a finite period of success. Siege euphoria from 9/11 and Iraq is wearing off, consumer confidence is drooping, leaving the administration with three choices; improve the economy by conventional methods trying to use a badly broken, unrepairable at this stage manufacturing sector, expand the active war effort for another temporary fix or bite the bullet and take the economic hit to reduce the standard of living. That's how important consumer confidence is to the US economy. Any guesses?

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  The Export of Jobs
